docs.lead_paragraph: Dorothy Knight has dressed up her son's ventilator with three Mickey Mouse stickers, but there is no hiding the hospital in her house. A tank of oxygen sits by the crib, a few feet from the machine that tracks 2-year-old Jimmy's heart rate and blood oxygen while he sleeps. She is casual about her dual role as mother and nurse, yet it is still unsettling when she flips on a little electric pump -- dug out from a pile of toys -- sticks a catheter through the tracheotomy tube in Jimmy's throat, then suctions out the excess mucus.

headline.main: HEALTH CARE COMES HOME: A special report.; Families Provide Medical Care, Tubes and All

docs.abstract: Special report, Health Care Comes Home, describes how thousands of families are providing unprecedented amount of technical medical care in their homes, much of which would once have been provided by doctors or nurses; reasons for shift include technology that makes even complicated treatments possible at home and intense pressure to reduce hospital costs; home care can be beneficial for patients and relatives, but also places huge burdens of time and energy on relatives; Dorothy Knight describes caring for her young son, Carol Levine for her brain-injured husband, Regina Cunningham for her daughter and Phyllis Kaufman for her husband; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: At Harry Knobbe's Feed Yards the other day, Senator Chuck Hagel was holding forth on the global economy, the Asian financial crisis and the International Monetary Fund with a dozen or so hog and cattle farmers. Here in Cuming County, one of the largest cattle-producing counties in the United States, the farmers were hanging on every word.
docs.abstract: Profile of freshman US Sen Chuck Hagel, Nebraska Republican; even as freshman Republican on Foreign Relations Committee, ranked 98th in seniority out of 100 Senators, he is proving an influential new voice in foreign affairs; at time when country is looking inward, Hagel, 51-year-old self-made millionaire, is preaching virtues of internationalism to Congress and public; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THANKS in part to the aging of the baby boomers, more ways to get fit -- without the pain often associated with exercise -- have now become available. That's because fitness involves almost as much mind as it does muscle. And with some of the latest exercise trends coming out of New York City in recent years, Connecticut finds itself more leading-edge than Johnny-come-lately in the movement to get people in motion, into shape and feeling better.

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR 80 years, workers at Fel-Pro Inc., a manufacturer of automotive parts based here, have enjoyed some of the lushest benefits in corporate America. The list is long and varied: as much as 12 weeks of vacation; scholarships; summer camp for employees' children; a fitness center; tutoring; the state's first licensed day-care center; use of a 250-acre corporate retreat, and even a $1,000 savings bond for the birth of an employee's child.

headline.main: Subjects Uneasy as a Benevolent Reign Ends

docs.lead_paragraph: The future of health care in this country is about to be decided yet again by advertising campaigns and sob stories. Some lobbyists and public relations firms, pushing for tougher regulations, are parading patients who tearfully complain of abuse by mean-spirited, money-hungry managed-care companies. Others claim that regulation will only lead to higher premiums and more uninsured people. Into this murky debate step members of Congress and state legislators, who are falling over themselves to offer legislation that would establish a ''patients' bill of rights.'' For the most part, these bills would force managed-care companies to pay for specific kinds of care, expand a patient's choice of doctors and require plans to document the outcome of the treatment.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Dr Susan Love says managed care has many problems, but it retains much potential; says passing quick-fix legislation will not help improve medical care; says employers must use their clout not only to lower health costs but also to improve quality; says public must demand that HMO's publicize their policies and guidelines, as well as defend them; says managed care should not be bashed, it should be improved; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In corporate conference rooms, in dentists' chairs and over dinner, the continuing news about both Viagra and Monica Lewinsky appears to have accelerated a change in the way many Americans speak about a subject that some would prefer be barely spoken about at all. In recent months, the subject of sex and the language describing sex acts and sex organs have been nudged a few inches closer to the conversationally commonplace. Many Americans say they have found themselves using words they would never previously have used, discussing erectile dysfunction at dinner parties, talking to their children about adultery, laughing (uncomfortably) at sex jokes told in the presence of people like their bosses.

headline.main: Speaking the Unspeakable (No Blushing Is Required)

docs.abstract: Introduction of Viagra, the drug for impotence, and allegations of Pres Clinton's relationship with Monica Lewinsky break down last remaining barriers in America to open and explicit discussion of sex and sexual organs; some observers say loosening of taboos on such talk has been going on for years, beginning with publication in 1948 of Alfred C Kinsey's book Sexual Behavior in the Human Male; others believe that people always talked and joked about sex and that the difference today is that the news media do it; those who see a real change differ on whether it is good or bad (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Health maintenance organization accountability and patient choice are not matter and anti-matter (Week in Review, May 31). The hallmark of managed care is supposed to be its disease prevention and management, which should already include systems that track medical outcomes. How can managed care companies, which cover health care for 80 percent of Americans, manage our health if they are not charting it? Because most patients receive their health plans through their employers, they can choose to vote with their feet only during a narrow open enrollment period -- once a year. Without outcome-driven data, patients will have no informed choice to make. JAMIE COURT Dir., Consumers for Quality Care Santa Monica, Calif., June 1, 1998
docs.abstract: Letter by Jamie Court, director of Consumers for Quality Care, comments on May 31 article; says health maintenance organization accountability and patient choice need not be mutually exclusive

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Thank you for revealing what the experts know and the politicians won't say about the consequences of enacting patients' rights legislation that mandates the collection of treatment outcome data (Week in Review, May 31). I do not want to sacrifice the right to choose my doctor for treatment outcome data that may or may not reflect quality of care.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your May 30 Business Day article on the use by health maintenance organizations of capitation payments to physicians -- lump sums for each patient they are responsible for instead of negotiated fees for each service -- overlooked the distinction between the effects of such payments on individual physicians and the effects on large, integrated groups of physicians.
docs.abstract: Letter by Dr Arnold S Relman, editor in chief emeritus of New England Journal of Medicine, comments on May 30 article; says medical ethicists find no fault with capitation payments to large medical groups but express reservations about such payments to individual doctors
